note_tweet_text:
You said you needed real-word tech skills, I'm giving it to you for free.

My next tech bootcamp starts in 10 days, and thousands of people will be active in the same cohort.

The last big one I did was 2 years ago and we have been preparing this bootcamp for 6 months.

We 40 industry real-world experts from all different domains so we can see all sides.

The bootcamp is focused on GenAI but let that not mislead you, you will be putting to practice all the fundamental technical skills to the test: Linux, Cloud, IT Networking, Programming, Containers, Solution Architecting.

My bootcamps are hard because they are real-world, we don't dilute things here. But they are so much easier when you are in the active-cohort because so many people are treading the same path, that all possible paths will be solved. This is your guaranteed way of upskilling.

My bootcamps are graded and we issue badges for different levels of grading, and there is risk of failure, if you're uncomfortable and failing than you are learning.

People who I have mentored in the past and failed to meet the goals I set out for them have gone onto become CTOs or entrepreneurs, because that's how much they learned.

The education you are going to receive is at least worth $10,000 USD but you can have it for $0 and this only works because of gracious volunteers, tech sponsors, the volume of bootcampers and because of my undying mission to make tech educational affordable.

If you need permission, than I permit you to join my bootcamp.
Not ready? You never will be, so time to jump in.

The link is in the reply.
cognitive_value: Enables tech skill building with free cohort-based bootcamp

author: NikkiSiapno
full_text:
Top 8 data structures we use every day:

Data structures are the building blocks of software, helping to organize and store information efficiently.

They are not just theoretical concepts; they are used in the applications that we interact with daily.

Here are some real-world https://t.co/uGuC1sesUR
note_tweet_text:
Top 8 data structures we use every day:

Data structures are the building blocks of software, helping to organize and store information efficiently.

They are not just theoretical concepts; they are used in the applications that we interact with daily.

Here are some real-world examples of how these data structures are used:

🔸 List

Online shopping cart — an ordered collection of items with the ability to access items at specific positions.

🔸 Linked List

Browser history — enables quick and efficient traversal backward and forward through the history.

🔸 Hash Table

Caching — Many caching algorithms, like in web browsers and content delivery systems, use hash tables to quickly look up values based on a key.

🔸 Stack

Undo functionality — Last In, First Out (LIFO) the last element added is the first one to be removed.

🔸 Queue

Printer queue — follows the First In, First Out (FIFO) principle, print jobs are processed in the order they are received.

🔸 Graph

Social media network — helps in suggesting new friends, finding mutual connections, and disseminating posts through the network.

🔸 Matrix

Pathfinding — utilizes a two-dimensional array to represent a grid and determine the shortest path from one point to another.

🔸 Tree

File system — trees are hierarchical in nature, mirroring the organizational structure of directories and subdirectories. Many file systems are represented as trees with directories as nodes.

🔸 Heap

Priority queue — efficiently ensures that the element with the highest priority is always readily accessible.

Of course, these are just a few examples of the many data structures used in software engineering.

Understanding how and where to use these data structures is a fundamental skill for any software engineer to create effective and efficient solutions.

💭 I’d love to hear your thoughts. What data structures or use cases would you like to add? 💬

~~

author: svpino

Here is how you can install an open-source, enterprise-grade RAG system on your server (with the best document understanding I've seen.)

First, something obvious to anyone trying to sell RAG in the market: You are crazy if you think companies will let their data travel to a https://t.co/LoK7XRStan
note_tweet_text:
Here is how you can install an open-source, enterprise-grade RAG system on your server (with the best document understanding I've seen.)

First, something obvious to anyone trying to sell RAG in the market: You are crazy if you think companies will let their data travel to a hosted model.

No one wants to send their data anywhere (those who do haven't found an alternative.) Every single company would rather have an air-gapped system with no internet access.

GroundX is an open-source RAG system that you can run on your servers (or any cloud provider, as long as you have access to GPUs) and works without a network.

(If the military wants to do RAG, this is precisely what they will be looking for.)

I installed GroundX on my AWS account and recorded a video to show you how to use it.

There are two services you can use:

1. Ingest: This service uses a pretrained vision model to ingest and understand your knowledge base.

2. Search: This service combines text and vector search with a fine-tuned re-ranker model to retrieve information from your knowledge base.

A quick note about the Ingest service:

99% of people think they need better "retrieval" mechanisms. I think they need better "ingestion." That's where this service comes in!

Ingest "understands" your documents in a way I haven't seen before. After you try it, you'll realize why showing your LLM your raw documents is a bad idea.

In the video, I use a free tool called X-Ray to test a document and understand how the Ingest service breaks it down. You can access this tool by signing up for a free GroundX cloud account and uploading your documents.

You'll see a bit more about this in the video.
cognitive_value: Enables enterprise RAG deployment with local setup guide

author: StartupArchive_
full_text:
Gmail creator Paul Buchheit on how to build something 100 people love

As Paul, explains, he built the first version of Gmail in a day. Then he iterated his way to 100 people who loved the product:

“The whole thing was just iterating, step-by-step trying to build something that https://t.co/HNlkPu9xdb
note_tweet_text:
Gmail creator Paul Buchheit on how to build something 100 people love

As Paul, explains, he built the first version of Gmail in a day. Then he iterated his way to 100 people who loved the product:

“The whole thing was just iterating, step-by-step trying to build something that made people happy.”

The team decided that they needed to have 100 happy users before launching Gmail to the world. To achieve this, Paul embedded a quick questionnaire in the interface that asked users:

“Are you happy? Yes or No”

Paul would then seek out all of the “No” responders and ask them directly: “What will it take to make you a happy user?”

He ignored feedback from the people who said things like “it basically needs to be a clone of Outlook” because they were very unlikely to become happy users.

But other people just needed a minor feature or a bug fix. So Paul just worked on these easier requests to convert people to happy users one-by-one.

Email was 30 years old when Paul started building gmail, and it’s pretty much impossible to enter a space like that and build something that appeals to everyone. If you try, what you will end up building is a mediocre product that nobody really loves.

What Paul recommends doing instead—and what he did with gmail—is:

“Build a thing that has really deep appeal. Even if it’s to just a tiny fraction of people—if you can make that small fraction of people obsessively love what you’re building, it’s easier to just grow that group. There’s always people at the margin where if you make the thing slightly better, they’re going to join into that group. It’s easier to start with deep, narrow appeal and broaden it over time than it is to start with broad ‘meh’ and convert ‘meh’ to loving your thing en masse.”

Video source: @ycombinator (2018)
cognitive_value: Enables product iteration with Gmail creator case study

author: steventey
full_text:
Campsite just open-sourced their codebase and it's a treasure trove of great engineering principles:

◆ @nextjs – frontend
◆ S3 + @imgix – storage + CDN
◆ @pusher – notifications
◆ @100mslive – video chat
◆ @openai – AI
◆ @ToDesktop – native Mac app
◆ @vercel – deployment https://t.co/HyhfYHWtEF
cognitive_value: Enables engineering principles with open-source codebase study

author: TheChiefNerd
full_text:

ROGAN: "What did they take?"

cognitive_value: Enables health awareness with alternative treatment discussion

author: gregisenberg
full_text:
30 STARTUP IDEAS TO BUILD IN 2025 (ai agents, saas, tools etc)

1.  99designs but done by agents, called 99agents. Everything costs $9.99. $100M/year opportunity.

2. Agent called second opinion dot com. When you need a second opinion on something, DM it, AI answers. $20/month.
note_tweet_text:
30 STARTUP IDEAS TO BUILD IN 2025 (ai agents, saas, tools etc)

1.  99designs but done by agents, called 99agents. Everything costs $9.99. $100M/year opportunity.

2. Agent called second opinion dot com. When you need a second opinion on something, DM it, AI answers. $20/month.

3. AI agent scanning Airbnb for buying opportunities. Agent handles all outreach and initial negotiation. $2500/month

4. agent that turns highest-performing sales calls into videos with avatars for video content and sales emails. $2k/month.

5. platform letting enterprises rent idle AI compute to others. $500k/year wasted on unused GPUs. take 10% of marketplace.

6. agent finding profitable chrome extensions being killed by manifest v3 changes. 41% of chrome extensions are not compatible with manifest v3 changes. buy cheap, rebuild better, 10x price.

7. AI that turns support ticket patterns into auto-generated documentation. $200/month.

8. tool that identifies which newsletter writers have high engagement, good organic growth but terrible monetization. partner with them, 5x revenue in 6 months and split upside.

9. agent scanning CRM to predict which deals actually close vs just inflate pipeline. $400/month.

10. AI analyzing customer feedback to find hidden product opportunities. stop building wrong features. $3k/month. Sell to fast growing VC-backed companies.

11.  AI that builds custom agents from company documentation. not just knowledge base - full AI employees cloned from top performers. $10k/month/company.

12. agent monitoring when enterprise features get built by multiple customers. instant roadmap. $5k/month.

13. buy underperforming dev tools (100-500k ARR), add AI layer to automate support and onboarding. flip for 3x in 12 months.

14. AI that creates custom training paths based on role performance data. $500/month.

15. agent identifying which customer behaviors predict churn 90 days out. $400/month.

16. Agencies around ai tools that have raised $100M in last 12 months. Build productized service. Charge $3000/mo. Eventually they acquire you.

17. buy niche SaaS tools with loyal users but no AI features. add agents, double value, increase prices.

18. agent that turns sales call patterns into predictive playbooks. learn which discounts actually grow LTV vs just close deals. $500/month.

19. agent turning customer success patterns into automated playbooks. $300/month.

20. tool that identifies which product tutorials actually increase retention, uses agent to do tutorial optimization and eventually CRO. $500/month.

21. AI monitoring when teams accidentally rebuild existing features. save dev time. $500/month.

22. platform that turns support chat patterns into automated responses. $500/month.

23. agent finding which customer segments have highest expansion potential and helps close deals $5k/month.

24. AI that creates personalized sales decks from closed deal patterns. $2k/month.

25. tool identifying which feature requests come from highest LTV customers. $3k/month.

26. agent scanning when enterprise teams build internal tools. spot opportunities. $5k/month.

27. Agent that monitors employees contributions and gives bonuses based on variety of criteria like how well people like working with them to how much product they have shipped. $25/user

28. Tool that finds when companies' internal tools get more GitHub stars than their main product. catch spin-out opportunities early. $2k/month.

29. agent finding when teams solve same problems differently. standardize workflows. $5k/month.

30. IMDB for creators. SEO traffic. Eventually turn into the LinkedIn for creators. Broker deals, sell data. Get acquired by Google one day.

build something people need. make it simple. make it do one thing, one thing well. charge money. leverage tech thats already out there. 

don’t bookmark this, build it, share it with friends to find collaborators. im rooting for you

good luck.
cognitive_value: Enables startup ideation with 30 AI-first business ideas
